column27: The Environmental Development Policy Loan Program (ENVDPL) aims at supporting the government's efforts to strengthen environmental governance and institutions in Peru, and mainstream environmental sustainability in the development agenda of key sectors (mining, fisheries, and urban transport and energy). The ENVDPL promotes improvements in health particularly of the poor who are exposed to the highest risks from environmental degradation. The ENVDPL is consistent with one of the key pillars of the 2006 Country Partnership Strategy (CPS) for Peru for FY07-FY11 (and the 2009 CPS progress report) laying out a strategy to support the Government of Peru (GoP) to achieve its goals of sustained economic growth. The CPS recognizes the need to raise the profile of environmental issues in Peru by enhancing environmental public investments and strengthening the institutional framework. In support of the CPS' pillar on economic growth, the ENVDPL program will contribute to making growth environmentally sustainable by supporting the environmental legal and institutional framework, biodiversity conservation, enhancing control over air and water pollution, improving the sustainability of the mining sector and the sustainable management of fisheries resources. In addition, by supporting the policy instruments of the newly created Ministry of Environment (MINAM), the ENVDPL would contribute to the modernization of the state institutions.

column2: Peru Vilcanota Valley Protection and Development Project (Vilcanota II)
column3: World Bank - International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
column25: All site preservation activities|Protecting critical infrastructure|Rail infrastructure, rail equipment, locomotives, other rolling stock|Strengthening early warning systems|Response preparedness and sustainable recovery|Tourism policy and administrative management, activities unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in this group|Municipal and industrial solid waste management|Collection, disposal and treatment|Road infrastructure, road vehicles|Disaster risk assessment and monitoring|Institutional consensus, awareness, and capacity building|Disaster prevention and preparedness, activity unspecified
column27: The main components of the proposed project will be the following:11. Component 1 – Ollantaytambo Road and Rail Bypass (US$12 million).  The road and rail bypass of the town of Ollantaytambo is critical to the survival and preservation of that town’s historic center, currently being damaged by vibrations and pollution from the heavy traffic crossing it daily.  The proposed bypass would divert commercial and tourism-related traffic, allowing for monument preservation, pedestrian safety, pollution reduction, and improved traffic circulation, as well as making the center more walkable and pleasant for tourists and residents alike.  This component will build on the diagnosis, feasibility studies (including the Environmental Impact Assessment, or EIA), and designs currently being financed under the Vilcanota I Project.12. Component 2 – Solid Waste Management System for the Provinces of Calca, Cusco, and Urubamba (US$15 million).  The precarious dumps currently used for solid waste disposal by the Provinces of Calca, Cusco, and Urubamba, and the large amounts of uncollected waste in the region, have a negative impact on public health, the environment, the local landscape, and tourism.  This component will build on the diagnosis, feasibility studies (including the EIA), and designs currently being financed under the Vilcanota I Project, to support the implementation of a new regional system of solid waste collection, transportation, and disposal.13. Component 3 – Disaster Risk Management and Preparedness (US$21 million).  The town of Machu Picchu Pueblo (also known as Aguas Calientes) has a high level of exposure to natural disasters, due to its peculiar geophysical location.  The area is under further stress, as the main access to the Historic Sanctuary of Machu Picchu (HSMP).  The town has a poor record of protection by national and local institutions.  Building on the work begun under Vilcanota I, the DRM work under this component will include an early warning system for flash floods, an evacuation plan, enhancement of medical facilities for trauma patients, selected public works for risk mitigation, public information campaigns and regular preparedness drills, etc.  This part of Component 3 will build on the diagnosis, feasibility study, and designs currently being financed under the Vilcanota I Project.  Disaster risk management and preparedness needs in Cusco and the broader Vilcanota Valley will also be assessed during project preparation, and a program of investments developed, including the strengthening of essential structures, such as schools and hospitals.14. Component 4 – Improvement and Access to Historic and Heritage Sites (US$16 million).  Important heritage sites around Cuzco and the Vilcanota Valley, such as Maras, Moray, Tipón, Huchuy Qosqo and Patapata, will receive restoration works under this component. Also, pedestrian pathways and access roads to these monuments will be paved or improved. Better preservation and better access will make these archeological sites more attractive and easier to visit, diversifying options for tourists and potentially lengthening their stays in the area. This is a key objective of the national and regional tourism authorities, as it directly boosts the local service economy.15. Component 5 – Project Management, Studies, and Capacity Building (US$6 million).  This component will include project management support, institutional capacity building, and all studies to be undertaken under Vilcanota II.  These studies will include comprehensive tourism planning to improve services for tourists (e.g., tourist information offices), and to ensure pro-poor tourism development, so as to allow poor local communities to equitably participate in the benefits of the business and job opportunities arising from tourism.  Appropriate institutional arrangements for tourism development will be developed in dialogue with local municipalities, so as to avoid potential conflicts, redundancies, and overlap.

column27: The objective of the Second Programmatic Environmental Development Policy Loan (ENVDPL 2) Program is to support the government's efforts to strengthen environmental governance and institutions in Peru, and mainstream environmental sustainability in the development agenda of key sectors (mining, fisheries, and urban transport and energy). Within the scope of the ENVDPL program, this second ENVDPL is consistent with one of the key pillars of the 2006 Country Partnership Strategy (CPS) for Peru for FY07-FYI1 (and the 2009 CPS progress report) laying out a strategy to support the Government of Peru (GoP) to achieve its goals of sustained economic growth. The CPS recognizes the need to raise the profile of environmental issues in Peru by enhancing environmental public investments and strengthening the institutional framework. In support of CPS pillar one on economic growth, the ENVDPL program will contribute to making growth environmentally sustainable by supporting the environmental legal and institutional framework, biodiversity conservation, enhancing control over air and water pollution, improving the sustainability of the mining sector, and the sustainable management of fisheries resources. In addition, by supporting the policy instruments of the newly created Ministry of Environment (MINAM), the ENVDPL program will contribute to the modernization of the state institutions (CPS pillar three).  The core sectors and themes to be supported by this Development Policy Loan (DPL) were selected based on the following: (a) a level of national priority identified by the Country Environmental Analysis (CEA) and agreed on by Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) and MINAM; (b) supplementary support from other loans and grants; and (c) the level of sectoral support and commitment.

column2: Peru Third Programmatic Environmental Development Policy Loan
column3: World Bank - International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
column12: MINISTRY OF ECONOMY AND FINANCE::Borrower|MINISTRY OF ECONOMY AND FINANCE::Borrower|
column25: Mineral and mining sector policy, planning and programs|Fishing sector policy, planning and programs|Community participation and development|All environmental education/training activities|Environmental policy, laws, regulations and economic instruments|Institution capacity building, Environmental protection
column27: The objectives of the Environmental Development Policy Loan Program (ENVDPL) are: (a) institutional strengthening for environmental governance, including regulation and enforcement; and (b) mainstreaming of environmental sustainability principles in the mining, fisheries, and urban transport and energy sectors. The first loan (ENVDPL 1) focused on the enactments of laws, and issuances of various decrees to define roles, set environmental standards, and approve regulations to improve environmental sustainability in the mining, urban transport and fisheries sectors. The second loan (ENVDPL 2) built on the previous operation, and supported the development and implementation of various programs, strategies and initiatives to strengthen environmental governance, and address environmental concerns in the key sectors. This operation (ENVDPL 3) continues efforts to boost environmental sustainability, and enhance capacity building and public participation. The Peruvian government also has mechanisms to ensure adequate consultations opportunities which include public audiences (commonly used in the mining and energy sectors) in order to discuss environmental and social concerns in an open and transparent manner.

column2: Sierra Irrigation Subsector

column25: Small system sewerage|Agricultural research, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Agricultural machinery/equipment|Water resources policy and administrative management, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Formal education/training, Agriculture|Irrigation|Agricultural development, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|All promotion of development awareness activities|Reservoirs|Environmental policy, laws, regulations and economic instruments|Agricultural financial services
column27: The objective of the Sierra Irrigation Project for Peru is to contribute to increasing agricultural production and productivity in targeted areas of the Sierra. There are five components to the project, the first component being modernization and rehabilitation of collective irrigation. This component will finance pre-investment studies and design, execution and supervision of subprojects to support eligible Water Users' Organization (WUO) to improve their water supply service to farmers, through the modernization or rehabilitation of collective irrigation systems, including, inter alia: water intakes improvement; canal improvement; and construction and rehabilitation of small water regulation reservoirs. The second component is the irrigation technology improvement. This component will finance pre-investment studies and design, execution and supervision of subprojects to support eligible farmers groups, and to increase irrigation performance at the farm level through the installation of improved on-farm irrigation systems. The third component is the capacity building and support to production and marketing. The fourth component is the formalization of water rights and national water rights administrative registry. Finally, the fifth component is the project implementation support. This component will support the provision of technical assistance, training, and acquisition and utilization of equipment to Irrigation Subsector Project (PSI) for: (a) the administration, monitoring, (including the base line study), evaluation and auditing of the project; and (b) the carrying out of awareness raising campaigns for all Sierra Water Users' Association (WUAs) on the implication of the new water law and on improved water management practices.

column27: En continuité avec les programmes précédents, la Fondation vise à l'inclusion des groupes sociaux et des communautés actuellement marginalisées, au plan social, politique ou économique. Les programmes reposent sur 5 axes stratégiques: 1) le renforcement des capacités des partenaires et des groupes de base à la planifiction et à la gestion; 2) le soutien à la participation populaire et au respect des droits de la personne; 3) le soutien au développement économique solidaire par l'amélioration de la production agricole et alimentaire respectueuse de l'environnement; 4) l'appui à des actions de santé primaire; et 5) l'appui à des programmes d'éducation de base.

column2: New REDD Models for Tropical Montane Forests
column26: NEW REDD MODELS FOR TROPICAL MONTANE FORESTS
column27: The project aims at developing an innovative REDD mechanism which reduces the frequency of destructive fires at the same time it alleviates poverty and conserves healthy Andean watersheds. This is achieved by working on reforestation of degraded lands using local foresters and indigenous communities. The idea is to develop REDD enterprise of non-timber forest products, indigenous participation, local ecotourism trade. Scientific component: extending research already underway on fire frequency, forest degradation, and carbon cycling in the high Andes. The project is designed as a scalable REDD mechanism ready to implement in other tropical regions, and incorporates five other strategies to strengthen REDD programs worldwide.

column27: Guía de educación ambiental para maestros de escuela. Publishing a 3rd -and updated- edition of the handbook on environmental education for school teachers' use in cooperation with Ministries of Education and Environment/ Peru, whole country. One of the main factors for environmental destruction and biodiversity loss in Peru is its people's lack of information about environmental issues. This handbook -the first of its kind- aims at building environmental awareness among the new generations since their school age.

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: LOCAL COOPERATION FUND (LCF) IN PERU
column27: Ojos de Agua. Setting up a conservancy concession over the Ojos de Agua forest, to protect the headwaters of the area, threatened by deforestation/ San Martin (North Western Amazonia). The Ojos de Agua forest covers 2 400 Has of public land over a hill range. The farmers at the feet of those hills have realized that the favourable climate of their valley and specially its water provision depend on the existence of that forest over the hills. They also got aware that, as the hills are public land, risk to be deforested not only by Andean colonizers but even by themselves as individuals looking to extend their properties. So they decided to reunite as an association to collectively take care of the hills. They have asked from the public administration the granting of a Conservation Concession over the area.

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: LOCAL COOPERATION FUND (LCF) IN PERU
column27: Micro programas ambientales. Production of a series of radio spots to inform the great public on environmental matters, raising awareness on climate change, its effects over local day to day life, and the local alternatives for adapting to it and contributing to its mitigation. To be broadcasted throughout an agreement with a nation wide reaching radio station./ Whole country. Peruvian average citizen is regularly unaware of environmental matters, thus, conservation and environmental sustainability are not amid Peruvian people main concerns. This is of course a strong contributing factor for environmental degradation and the poverty it carries on.

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru

column27: Conservación participativa de orquideas fase II. Participative conservation and sustainable use of the orchid Phragmipedia kovachii, endemic species of San Martin region./ San Martin (North Western Amazonia).The project seeks to save the species from extinction and help to preserve the whole forest in the area (a natural reserve, legally protected but threatened in practice by extractive activities of surrounding population) through the sensitization of local people to get them involved at the conservation of the few last patch relicts of the orchid species in wilderness while offering to them the possibility of getting monetary incomes from eco tourism and in vitro cultivation of the endangered orchid.

column27: EL PROYECTO PRETENDE FOMENTAR LAS OPORTUNIDADES Y CAPACIDADES TÉCNICASMATERIALES E INMATERIALES Y CULTURALES DE UNA COMUNIDAD DE PESCADORES ARTESANALES COMO ELEMENTO SUSTANCIAL DEL DESARROLLO HUMANO YNATURAL SOSTENIBLE ENTENDIDO COMO MECANISMO PARA SUPERAR LA POBREZA, LA DESIGUALDAD E INJUSTICIA, ASÍ MISMO PRETENDE APOYAR Y FOMENTARUN CRECIMIENTO ECONÓMICO INCLUSIVO, EQUITATIVO, SOSTENIDO Y RESPETUOSO CON EL MEDIO AMBIENTE. ESTA NUEVA FORMA DE TURISMO CULTURALY DE NATURALEZA POTENCIA EL USO SOSTENIBLE DE LOS RECURSOS MARINO-COSTERO PERMITIRÁ INCENTIVAR LA PARTICIPACIÓN ACTIVA DE LOS PESCADORESARTESANALES EN LA PRESERVACIÓN Y CONSERVACIÓN DE LA BIODIVERSIDAD DEL ENTORNO NATURAL. ASÍ MISMO FOMENTARÁ ENTRE LOS VISITANTES Y TURISTASEL CONOCIMIENTO DE LOS EQUIPOS DE PESCA, VIVENCIAS Y DESTREZAS DE LA PRÁCTICA DIARIA DE LA PESCA ARTESANAL Y EL RESPETO AL DESARROLLOSOSTENIBLE Y PRESERVACIÓN DEL MEDIO AMBIENTE EN COORDINACIÓN Y COLABORACIÓN CON LA ASOCIACIÓN HIPÓLITO SOTO BERNAOLA (PISCO) Y ELINSTITUTO DEL MAR DEL PERÚ (IMARPE), LABORATORIO DE PISCO, SE PREVÉ LAS SIGUIENTES ACCIONES EN 4 FASES: 1-FORMACIÓN ESPECÍFICA DE LOSPESCADORES ARTESANALES. TEMA: #TURISMO CULTURAL Y DE NATURALEZA#. 2-TRABAJO DE CAMPO. ELABORACIÓN DE UN REGISTRO PORMENORIZADODE LOS EQUIPOS Y PROCEDIMIENTOS PESQUEROS SUSCEPTIBLES DE INCORPORARLOS AL PROYECTO. 3-A PARTIR DE LA INFORMACIÓN RECOGIDA, ANALIZAR YESTUDIAR LAS DIFERENTES PROPUESTAS, ITINERARIOS, REQUERIMIENTOS TÉCNICOS Y COSTOS. 4-ELABORACIÓN DE UNA WEB PROMOCIONAL, MATERIAL DIDÁCTICOINFORMATIVO E IMPLEMENTACIÓN DE MATERIAL Y EQUIPOS.

column2: Voluntary Cooperation Programme / Programme de coopération volontaire
column26: VOLUNTARY COOPERATION PROGRAMME / PROGRAMME DE COOPÉRATION VOLONTAIRE
column27: SUCO's three-month VCP program proposal aims to consolidate the achievements of the five-year program that ended on March 31, 2009. Activities in this regard will focus on consolidating the new knowledge and practices that partners have acquired, as well as developing tools to evaluate, systematize, and capitalize on experience. SUCO will mainly focus its efforts on three CIDA priorities: promoting good governance, supporting private-sector development, and promoting environmental sustainability, with a view to partner capacity-building. SUCO will also help Canadians to learn more about, and become more involved in, development and solidarity among peoples. All activities undertaken in countries of intervention will help to reduce poverty and to promote equality between women and men. / La proposition de trois (3) mois du PCV de SUCO est orienté vers le renforcement des connaissances et des nouvelles pratiques acquises par les partenaires et le développement d'outils d'évaluation, de systématisation et de capitalisation des expériences. Les efforts de SUCO seront concentrés principalement dans trois secteurs prioritaires de l'ACDI: la promotion de la bonne gouvernance, le soutien au développement du secteur privé et la promotion de la viabilité de l'environnement dans une optique de renforcement des capacités des partenaires. Ils contribueront également à accroître l'éducation et l'engagement du public canadien en faveur du développement et de la solidarité entre les peuples. Toutes les actions entreprises dans les pays d'intervention contribueront à la réduction de la pauvreté et à la promotion de l'égalité entre les femmes et les hommes.

column2: Coady International Institute - International Internships 2009-2012 / Coady International Institute - Stages internationaux 2009-2012
column9: COADY INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTE ST. FRANCIS XAVIER UNIVERSITY
column26: COADY INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTE - INTERNATIONAL INTERNSHIPS 2009-2012 / COADY INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTE - STAGES INTERNATIONAUX 2009-2012
column27: This project is part of CIDA's International Youth Internship Program (IYIP), funded by Canada's Youth Employment Strategy (YES). It is designed to offer young Canadian post-secondary graduates the opportunity to gain professional experience through international cooperation work. As a general rule, CIDA provides up to $15,000 per internship to Canadian organizations that manage the internship and recruit interns. / Ce projet fait partie du programme de stages internationaux pour les jeunes (PSIJ) de l'ACDI, programme financé par la Stratégie emploi jeunesse (SEJ) du gouvernement du Canada. Le programme offre à des jeunes Canadiennes et Canadiens récemment diplômés (collège ou université) une expérience professionnelle de travail pratique dans le domaine de la coopération internationale. L'ACDI verse normalement un maximum de 15 000 $ par stage à des organisations canadiennes qui gèrent les stages et recrutent les stagiaires.

column2: Conference: Rethinking Extractive Industry: Regulation, Dispossession, and Emerging Claims / Conférence : Rethinking Extractive Industry: Regulation,
column26: CONFERENCE: RETHINKING EXTRACTIVE INDUSTRY: REGULATION, DISPOSSESSION, AND EMERGING CLAIMS / CONFÉRENCE : RETHINKING EXTRACTIVE INDUSTRY: REGULATION,
column27: This project enables the participation of representatives from eligible countries at the conference ''Rethinking Extractive Industry: Regulation, Dispossession, and Emerging Claims'' in Toronto, Ontario, from March 5 to 7, 2009. The conference responds to growing public debate and academic interest in the increasing numbers of social, political, and environmental issues and conflicts that are being generated by the recent rapid growth of mining and petroleum industries in Canada, the Americas, and Africa. / Ce projet permet aux représentants des pays admissibles de participer à la conférence intitulée « Rethinking Extractive Industry: Regulation, Dispossession, and Emerging Claims », tenue à Toronto (Ontario), du 5 au 7 mars 2009. La conférence faire écho à la hausse des débats publics et de l'intérêt des universitaires concernant la multiplication des enjeux et des conflits sociaux, politiques et environnementaux engendrés par la croissance rapide des industries minières et pétrolières au Canada, dans les Amériques et en Afrique.

column2: Improving Vocational Training / Améliorer la formation professionnelle
column9: Éducation International-Coopérative de Services de Développement et
column26: IMPROVING VOCATIONAL TRAINING / AMÉLIORER LA FORMATION PROFESSIONNELLE
column27: The project contributes to poverty reduction in the underprivileged municipality of Comas, nearby Lima, by facilitating youth and workers access to vocational training in general mechanics to meet private sector needs. A strategy is also being implemented to facilitate access to vocational training for women. The project proposes to upgrade the Collegio Técnico Experimental Jesus Obrero (CTEJO) installations and equipment so that it adapts itself to the technological changes and the needs of the labor market and the private sector enterprises. The project also aims at improving school management by integrating a permanent dialogue with these enterprises. Finally, the project has also for objective the addition of a new continuous learning program in general mechanics delivered during evenings. / Ce projet a pour but de réduire la pauvreté dans la municipalité défavorisée de Comas, située près de Lima, en favorisant l'accès des jeunes et des travailleurs à une formation professionnelle en mécanique générale qui réponde aux besoins du secteur privé. Une stratégie est également mise en oeuvre afin de favoriser l'accessibilité de la formation professionnelle aux femmes. Pour ce faire, le projet propose d'actualiser les installations et les équipements du Collegio Técnico Experimental Jesus Obrero (CTEJO) afin de s'adapter aux changements technologiques et aux besoins du marché du travail et des entreprises. En intégrant un dispositif permanent de dialogue avec ces dernières, le projet vise aussi à améliorer la gestion du CTEJO. Enfin, le projet a également pour objectif l'ajout d'un nouveau programme de formation continue de mécanique générale dispensé en soirée.

column2: CUSO-VSO Program Support April-June 2009 / CUSO-VSO Appui au programme avril-juin 2009
column26: CUSO-VSO PROGRAM SUPPORT APRIL-JUNE 2009 / CUSO-VSO APPUI AU PROGRAMME AVRIL-JUIN 2009
column27: CUSO-VSO Program Support April-June 2009 This six-month agreement is a continuation of support to CUSO-VSO that will enable it to make a transition from its current program (2004-2009), to a new 5-year program that is currently under consideration by Treasury Board for approval in Summer/Fall 2009. Under this transition agreement, CUSO-VSO will place 55 volunteers globally as part of existing and new partnerships in five thematic areas: Education, HIV/AIDS, Participation and Governance/Access to Justice for Women & Children, Youth Social and Economic Inclusion, Environmental Protection, with Gender Equality as a cross-cutting theme. Volunteers will be placed in 7 countries in Africa (Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Ghana, Nigeria, Rwanda, Tanzania), 7 countries in Latin America & Caribbean (Bolivia, El Salvador, Guatemala, Guyana, Honduras, Jamaica, Peru), and 1 in Asia (Indonesia). Volunteers can be North-South (Canadian citizens or landed immigrants placed in the South); South-South (Southerners volunteering in other Southern countries; National (Southerners volunteering in their own country); Diaspora (members of Diaspora groups in the North placed in their origin countries); South-North (Southern volunteers placed in Canada). The program's Public Engagement component will increase Canadian public understanding of international development issues and the value of volunteer cooperation; contribute to increased dialogue about international development and Canada's contribution; and engage various Canadian organizations in collaborations with Southern counterparts. / À venir

column2: Mapacho River Watershed Environment / Environnement du bassin hydrologique de la rivière Mapacho
column9: One Sky - The Canadian Institute of Sustainable Living
column26: MAPACHO RIVER WATERSHED ENVIRONMENT / ENVIRONNEMENT DU BASSIN HYDROLOGIQUE DE LA RIVIÈRE MAPACHO
column27: The project aims to: - research and develop a local community economic development plan based on ecological governance and the sustainable use of natural resource; - develop the capacity of the local partner and the community to effectively engage in policy dialogue regarding natural resources; - develop and implement an integrally informed leadership training program with an emphasis on environmental education for local leaders; - develop an environmental education curriculum that links the Millenium Development Goals with Multilateral Environmental Agreements including the biodiversity convention and climate change in the context of local economic development alternatives. / Le projet vise à: - rechercher et préparer un plan de développement économique communautaire basé sur la gouvernance écologique et l'utilisation durable des ressources naturelles; - développer les capacités du partenaire local ainsi que celles de la communauté pour qu'ils s'engagent efficacement dans le dialogue sur les politiques concernant les ressources naturelles; - développer et mettre en oeuvre un programme de formation intégral en leadership axé sur l'environnement pour les leaders locaux; - développer un programme d'étude environnemental qui lie les Objectifs de développement du millénaire avec des accords environnementaux multilatéraux comprenant la Convention sur la biodiversité et les changements climatiques dans le contexte des solutions de rechange en développement économique local.

column2: Conservation of the Sacred City of Caral
column26: CONSERVATION OF THE SACRED CITY OF CARAL
column27: Conservation of the Sacred City of Caral - To support the conservation of the Sacred City of Caral in the Supe Valley. Contemporaneous with the ancient civilizations of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and India, the Sacred City of Caral (3000-1800 BC) is often called the mother culture of the Americas. Its earthworks and buildings, which speak to the technological know-how and organizational complexity of Supe society, require conservation treatment to prevent irretrievable loss.. [Type: Conservation]

ATF conducts criminal investigations, regulates the firearms and explosives industries, and assists other law enforcement agencies. This work is undertaken to prevent terrorism, reduce violent crime and to protect the public.

column2: Physical Security Training and Protection of Cultural Heritage Sites in Ayacucho

column27: Physical Security Training and Protection of Cultural Heritage Sites in Ayacucho - To support the implementation of security measures and conservation treatments for collections in three regional museums in Ayacucho. This project, which continues work begun under a previous AFCP grant to support a security assessment at these museums, also involves conservation treatment of pre-Hispanic ceramic and textile collections.. [Type: Technical Support for Preservation]

column2: Preservation of Artifacts from the Chachapoya Fortress of Kuelap
column26: PRESERVATION OF ARTIFACTS FROM THE CHACHAPOYA FORTRESS OF KUELAP
column27: Preservation of Artifacts from the Chachapoya Fortress of Kuelap - To support the conservation and storage of archaeological artifacts at the Fortress of Kuelap. Occupied from the 6th to the 16th century, this massive fort is the only excavated residential site of the Chachapoya civilization. This project includes object conservation, the outfitting of storage space for artifacts, and technical training in conservation and data management for site staff.. [Type: Preservation]

column2: PERU/Life W Conservation a Ecological Restoration of Atiquipa
column26: PERU/LIFE W CONSERVATION A ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION OF ATIQUIPA
column27: The project aims for the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of the Atiquipa Lomas. The project emcompasses following components: 1) biodiversity conservation, 2) water resources management and 3) climate change adaptation. Overall Objective is to conserve and recover native lomas forest in Atiquipa and ensure its conservation through active participation of local actors. The project aims to improve the capacity of the lomas to sustain livelihoods through strengthened organizational capacities at the local level for sustainable management of natural resources and adaptation to climate change.

column2: PER/Recycling Center of Cuna Nazareth
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION/TRAINING
column27: The project establishes a recycling centre and trains unemployed young people to be professionals in recycling in Pachacamac, poor outskirts of Lima. The aim is to create a training system for recycling. The established centre sells material to industry and repaired items at low price to people in the area. The purpose is to make the centre self-sustaining during the project and to make profit in the future. The project also aims to improve environmental awareness of the people in Pachacamac.

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: BIO-DIVERSITY
column27: Support for the implementation of the Management Plan of the OJOS DE AGUA FOREST conservancy concession, set up to protect the headwaters of the area, threatened by deforestation/ San Martin (North Western Amazonia). The Ojos de Agua forest covers 2 400 Has of public land over a hill range. The farmers at the feet of those hills have realized that the favourable climate of their valley and specially its water provision depend on the existence of that forest over the hills. They also got aware that, as the hills are public land, risk to be deforested not only by Andean colonizers but even by themselves as individuals looking to extend their properties. So they decided to reunite as an association to collectively take care of the hills.

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: FORESTRY POLICY & ADMIN. MANAGEMENT
column27: Communal conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity at Pichis Valley. To alleviate poverty among indigenous communities by introducing the production of non wooden commercial items from communal forests outputs/ Eastern lowlands of Cerro de Pasco (Central Amazonia). This would be a continuation of a former one agreed as a complement to another Finnish funded project implemented by Conservation International, as a part of cooperation with DEVIDA (Peruvian national anti drug agency), on communal forest management as alternative development in contrast to illegal coca leaf plantations.

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: FORESTRY POLICY & ADMIN. MANAGEMENT
column27: Regional Natural Reserve and Cordillera Azul National Park, through the promotion of sustainable management of two native palms for the production of vegetal ivory and brooms. The communities would be getting involved in the extraction of non wooden forestry products with good commercial demand, which would give them a source of incomes alternative to logging or deforesting for introducing livestock./ San Martin (North Eastern Amazonia).

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY AND ADMIN. MGMT
column27: Capacity building for the Ombudsman's office to be better prepared to mediate in environmental conflicts and supervise the proper enforcement of environmental norms/ Peru, whole country.Environmental conflicts are multiplying across the country as a consequence of past bad practices by private companies, mainly in the mining industry, but also as a consequence of the already present effects of climate change, like the growing scarcity of water. In many cases, it is a matter of lack of dialogue or inadequate channels for it between entrepreneurs and local people. The ombudsman's office has become a key actor for preventing conflicts as it is sometimes the only one that is trusted and respected by all parts.

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY AND ADMIN. MGMT
column27: Introducing environmental matters like climate change and sustainable use of biodiversity into regional and municipal electoral debate in Amazonian region, through a forum assembling political candidates with local scholars, entrepreneurs, and representatives of civil society/ Loreto (Northern Amazonia).

column2: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Peru
column26: BIO-DIVERSITY
column27: Participative conservation and sustainable use of the orchid Phragmipedia kovachii, endemic species of San Martin region./ San Martin (North Western Amazonia). The project seeks to save the species from extinction and help to preserve the whole forest in the area (a natural reserve, legally protected but threatened in practice by extractive activities of surrounding population) through the sensitization of local people to get them involved at the conservation of the few last patch relicts of the orchid species in wilderness while offering to them the possibility of getting monetary incomes from eco tourism and in vitro cultivation of the endangered orchid.

column2: Swiss Subaccount at the International Monetary Fund for technical assistance in the South
column25: Forestry policy and administrative management, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Fuelwood/charcoal
column26: SWISS SUBACCOUNT AT THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN THE SOUTH
column27: Under the Letter of Understanding (LoU) South, SECO is financing through a dedicated Trust Fund (the Subaccount) TA implemented by the IMF in Africa, East Asia, and Latin America. Main goal of the TA provided under the Subaccount is to promote economic stability and sustainable growth, thereby contributing to poverty reduction in the recipient countries. Areas of intervention include: Public Finance Management, Anti Money Laundering and Combating the Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT), Financial Market Development, Pension Systems, and Central Banking. The Lou East covers the following recipient countries: Colombia, Egypt, Ghana, Indonesia, Peru, South Africa, Vietnam, Mozambique, Tanzania, Burkina Faso. -

column2: ACA Regional REDD Policy CFI 2010-12
column26: ACA REGIONAL REDD POLICY CFI 2010-12
column27: The project purpose is to protect Earth’s highest biodiversity hotspot and one of itsgreat centers of indigenous culture, while making fundamental contributions to developing REDD mechanisms by (1) developing a cost-reducing Decision Support Tool, which is a central impediment to effective REDD implementation in developing countries, (2) directly partnering with and thereby empowering indigenous stakeholders, (3) testing innovative REDD mechanisms that can be integrated into existing legal frameworks, (4) the introduction of cutting-edge REDD support tools, and (5) convening stakeholders to discuss and improve REDD project implementation.

column2: Complementary stage of the sustainable development project in the lower Huallaga (San martín, Peru), boosting and combining socio-economic conditions
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH
column27: Realización de un informe de sostenibilidad de la plantación agroforestal para la cual se llevó a cabo la previa planificación territorial. Este informe se basará en las técnicas más adecuadas que actualmente se emplean para este tipo de actividades en zonas de similares características socio-ambientales. Realización de un Plan de investigación que se basará en aquellos aspectos más sensibles en la socio-economía del lugar. Estudiando a la población, los flujos económicos y el desarrollo, tanto desde un punto de vista social como desde el ambiental. Para ello se buscarán las oportunidades agroforestales que puede presentar la zona, para ofrecerle a la población una alternativa a los actuales cultivos ilícitos, o a los sistemas agrarios que agotan el medio en donde son instalados. Realización de un Plan de desarrollo socio-económico apoyado en los estudios previos realizados para el plan de investigación. Se promocionará el cacao como cultivo ambiental, socialmente sostenible con el medio y económicamente viable. Así se impulsará la creación de una asociación de promotores de cacao del bajo Huallaga; incentivando igualmente la creación de un centro de acopio y de secaderos comunales para ordenar este tipo de cultivo en la comarca. La promoción de este tipo de acciones consideramos que puede ayudar a que el cultivo de cacao se instaure en la zona como una de las fuentes económicas y de desarrollo social para San Martín.

column2: Participative management for greenhouse gases reduction in brickyards in the Region of Cuzco (provinces of Cusco and Quispicanchis)
column9: Gabriel René Moreno Autonomus University of Valencia
column26: PARTICIPATIVE MANAGEMENT FOR GREENHOUSE GASES REDUCTION IN BRICKYARDS IN THE REGION OF CUZCO (PROVINCES OF CUSCO AND QUISPICANCHIS)
column27: La presente propuesta pretende incidir en el mejoramiento de la calidad del aire de tres distritos de Cusco: San Jerónimo en Cusco, Andahuaylillas y Lucre en Quispicanchis, debido a la presencia concentrada de la actividad ladrillera, que es la segunda actividad que más contaminantes emiten a la atmósfera debido a los sucios combustibles que usan en sus hornos: madera, aceite quemado y llantas viejas, y que perjudica no sólo la salud de los trabajadores del sector, sobre todo a mujeres y niños ya que el trabajo en la ladrillera es una actividad netamente familiar, sino también a los pobladores que viven cerca a estas unidades productivas. Por ello, el proyecto promoverá la adopción de buenas prácticas en la producción y gestión de las ladrilleras de modo que se aporte a reducir la emisión de gases efecto invernadero, mejorará la economía familiar de los ladrilleros y, sobre todo pondrá en agenda, al interior de las familias y la comunidad, los derechos de las mujeres del sector visibilizando su aporte. La población beneficiaria será de 2460 trabajadores involucrados en el sector ladrillero, agrupados en 410 unidades productivas y 5 asociaciones de ladrilleros. En general podemos decir que cerca del 80% de los productores presenta un nivel productivo artesanal.Por otro lado, debido a la carencia de normas y políticas locales que regulen el sector ladrillero, se aportará en la adopción de normas que promuevan un ambiente saludable y para ello se sensibilizará, capacitará y asesorará a las autoridades locales para que incorporen esta problemática en los Planes de Desarrollo y la gestión local. Se coordinará con las municipalidades distritales donde se ubican las unidades productivas así como la Dirección Regional de Producción para articular planes y normativas promoviendo la participación de 40 autoridades y funcionarios.Asimismo fortaleceremos a los líderes de la sociedad civil de las zonas involucradas para que promuevan mecanismos de vigilancia de los compromisos de las autoridades hacia el sector, compromisos que, en el mediano y largo plazo redundarán en la población en general del Cusco. Coordinaremos con 60 promotores ambientales, 20 por cada provincia, líderes y lideresas de las organizaciones sociales.Por último, se realizará una evaluación externa, al término del proyecto, para precisar las lecciones aprendidas y que nos permita replicar la experiencia en otras zonas del Cusco y del país.

column27: El MIRAN de la U. de Huelva como coordinador y socio tecnológico y la FAME como socio local pretenden desarrollar un programa de manejo integrado y sostenible de la plaga llamada “marabú” que incluye: Estudiar in situ las características biológicas de D. cinerea, distribución y dispersión. Realizar un inventario en Cuba de los posibles enemigos naturales de la especie invasora, valorando las posibilidades de éstos como potencial agente de control biológico. Evaluar prácticas agrotécnicas de control tradicionales de la especie. Evaluar diferentes métodos de control del marabú con productos naturales y químicos. Evaluar las potencialidades de uso alternativo del marabú en las pequeñas industrias locales del municipio de Trinidad. Seleccionar las prácticas de control más eficaces y comenzar su aplicación en el Valle.

column26: ENVIRONMENTAL RESTORATION & SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WITH ADAPTATION TO CLIMATE CHANGE APPROACH IN THREE DISTRICTS OF THE PROVINCE
column27: Proyecto: Restauración ambiental y gestión sostenible de los recursos naturales con perspectiva de adaptación al Cambio Climático en 3 distritos de la provincia de Lampa, cuenca alta Coata, Perú.Sector:(p5) “Protección del Medio Ambiente” debido a que contribuye en las siguientes líneas:- Capacitación y formación de las organizaciones comunitarias y personas con responsabilidades directas en la gestión ambiental y el manejo sostenible de los recursos naturales.- Promoción de estructuras participativas que integren a las organizaciones comunitarias en la gestión ambiental.- Apoyo a programas de conservación y gestión sostenible de la biodiversidad y los ecosistemas vulnerables.- Promoción del uso eficiente de la energía- Apoyo a la gestión sostenible de la biodiversidad1.Localización:2.Objetivos:Gestión y adaptación ambiental al Cambio Climático3.Resultados: I) Mejora de la gestión de 1 Recursos agrarios, 2 Recursos forestales 3 Residuos sólidos II). Sensibilización. 4.Población objetivo:Población beneficiaria Directa: Hombres: 679 y Mujeres: 719Población beneficiaria Indirecta: Hombres: 292 y Mujeres: 3055. Período de duración del proyecto:24 meses6. Período de tiempo para el que se solicita subvención: 24 meses

column2: Promotion of community environmental education for the improvement of population's quality of life of the micro-basin of San Pedro, Altos de Frías -
column26: PROMOTION OF COMMUNITY ENVIRONMENTAL EDUC. FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF POPULATION'S QUALITY OF LIFE OF THE MICRO-BASIN OF SAN PEDRO, ALTOS DE FRÍAS - PIUR
column27: La presente propuesta que presenta ESF con la Asociación Chira pretende contribuir al desarrollo integral de la educación de las comunidades del distrito de Frías, Piura. Perú. Para ello, se articulará la escuela pública con las familias y las asociaciones locales, para generar modelos de desarrollo acordes con el medio ambiente desde la educación ambiental.La propuesta abarca el espacio geográfico, ecológico y sociocultural de la micro cuenca de San Pedro.Se articularán 20 escuelas en la Red Educativa Rural de la micro cuenca de San Pedro 1 Centro de Capacitación Comunal, que favorecerá su cobertura, calidad pedagógica y acceso a las Nuevas Tecnologías.Complementada con la puesta en marcha de 20 proyectos medio ambientales y/o productivos

column2: Elderly educating for development 2010
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY AND ADMIN. MGMT
column27: Mejorar el control del territorio y la fiscalización de los impactos de las actividades petroleras por parte de las comunidades Quechua de la amazonía peruana y su federación representativa (Federación Indígena Quechua del Pastaza (FEDIQUEP)) mediante el fomento de las capacidades locales. A través de implementar un sistema de monitorización indígena, procesos de fortalecimiento organizativo, acciones de incidencia, sensibilización y procesos legales, pretende buscar mayor transparencia y responsabilidad en las prácticas operacionales de la industria extractiva para asegurar la implementación real de los derechos indígenas y posibilitar su desarrollo sostenible.

column2: ND
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY AND ADMIN. MGMT
column27: Desarrollar capacidades de diálogo político de la sociedad civil con las autoridades recién electas, a nivel local, regional y nacional para concertar políticas para lograr Ciudades Sostenibles (prevención de conflictos medioambientales, gestión del riesgo ante desastres naturales y seguridad ciudadana). Conjuga acciones de formación, incidencia política y visibilización macro-regional de estrategias creativas de concertación intersectorial.

column2: ND
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION/TRAINING
column27: Pretende contribuir a la disminución de la contaminación ambiental en la región, con tres líneas de trabajo: 1) Mejorar las capacidades de las comunidades campesinas para gestionar el agua y los residuos sólidos; 2) Que las políticas regionales favorezcan el cuidado del medio ambiente, sensibilizando a la población; 3) mayor control ambiental de la producción de residuos. Así se plantea la creación de un observatorio del medio ambiente.

column2: ND
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION/TRAINING
column27: Fortalecer las capacidades conceptuales, actitudinales de todos los pobladores de la provincia de Urubamba, fomentando la participación activa y decidida a través de un proceso de sensibilización contra los efectos de cambio climático y la lucha contra la pobreza, asumiendo roles y responsabilidades de control, seguridad y prevención de desastres naturales

column2: ND
column26: ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION/TRAINING
column27: Involucrar a familias de pescadores- agricultores de mar en la participación comunitaria y asociativa del desarrollo de capacidades productivas y asociativas y de manejo de la información, el conocimiento y la comunicación en todo aquello relacionado con el trabajo, las pràcticas democráticas, la conservación de la salud y del medio ambiente, y también su posicionamiento en el mercado a través de la producción y en la vida social a través de su participación activa de sus deberes y obligaciones con igualdad entre hombres y mujeres.

column27: CONTRIBUIR A LA DISMINUCIÓN DE LA CONTAMINACIÓN AMBIENTAL EN LA REGIÓN DE APURÍMAC TENIENDO COMO OBJETIVO LA REDUCCIÓN DEL DETERIORO DE ECOSISTEMAS PLUVIALES EN LAS COMUNIDADES CAMPESINAS DE LA REGIÓN.

column2: ND
column26: BIO-DIVERSITY
column27: El proyecto se localiza en una área de bosque tropical de la cuenca del río Pastaza, a la región de Loreto en la Amazonía septentrional peruana fronteriza con el Ecuador. Tiene como población destinataria los Quechua del Pastaza, una etnia que practica una economía de subsistencia y depende del bosque tropical y los ríos por su alimentación, medicina, recursos y su vida espiritual. Su territorio forma parte de un gran complejo de zonas húmedas denominado el Abanico del Pastaza, una área prioritaria para la conservación, protegida por el Convenio de Ramsar. A pesar de esta protección es una área afectada por más de 40 años de actividad petrolera que lo han convertido en el área de mayor producción de hidrocarburos de todo el país. El proyecto tiene por objetivo mejorar el control del territorio y la fiscalización, por parte de las comunidades Quechua y su federación representativa, de los impactos de las actividades petroleras. A través de este control y fiscalización se espera incidir positivamente en la salud de la población, la sostenibilidad ambiental de su territorio y el cambio de las prácticas operacionales indebidas de la industria petrolera. Por medio del fomento de las capacidades locales y la documentación de los impactos generados por las actividades hidrocarburíferos a la región; a través de implementar un sistema de monitorización indígena de los derramamientos de crudo, aguas de formación y otros residuos tóxicos subproductos de la actividad petrolera, de acciones de incidencia, sensibilización y procesos legales, se incidirá para aumentar la transparencia y responsabilidad en las prácticas operacionales de la industria extractiva para asegurar la implementación real de los derechos indígenas y posibilitar su desarrollo sostenible.

column27: This project is part of CIDA's International Youth Internship Program (IYIP), funded by Canada's Youth Employment Strategy (YES). It is designed to offer young Canadian post-secondary graduates the opportunity to gain professional experience through international cooperation work. As a general rule, CIDA provides up to $15,000 per internship to Canadian organizations that manage the internship and recruit interns. / Ce projet fait partie du programme de stages internationaux pour les jeunes (PSIJ) de l'ACDI, programme financé par la Stratégie emploi jeunesse (SEJ) du gouvernement du Canada. Le programme offre à des jeunes Canadiennes et Canadiens récemment diplômés (collège ou université) une expérience professionnelle de travail pratique dans le domaine de la coopération internationale. L'ACDI verse normalement un maximum de 15 000 $ par stage à des organisations canadiennes qui gèrent les stages et recrutent les stagiaires.

column2: Restoration of the Rocas Canal at the Ancient Site of Chavín de Huántar
column26: RESTORATION OF THE ROCAS CANAL AT THE ANCIENT SITE OF CHAVÍN DE HUÁNTAR
column27: To support the restoration of the original 400-meter underground drainage channel at the site of this important pre-Inca city and World Heritage Site. Situated where landslides, earthquakes, and rivers threaten it, Chavín de Huántar is sinking due to humidity and inadequate water drainage in the area. The project involves emergency conservation and reactivation of Rocas Canal as the first of many restoration measures intended to preserve the site.

column2: Restoration of 17th- and 18th-Century Paintings from the Compañia de Jesus Church in Arequipa
column26: RESTORATION OF 17TH- AND 18TH-CENTURY PAINTINGS FROM THE COMPAÑIA DE JESUS CHURCH IN AREQUIPA
column27: To support the restoration of 14 colonial paintings in the collection of the Jesuit church in the historic center of Arequipa, a World Heritage Site. First encountered during a project supported under a previous Ambassadors Fund grant to inventory and register ethnographic objects in and around Arequipa, the 14 paintings are in advanced stages of deterioration. This project involves the restoration of the paintings and their original frames in an on-site workshop, using the talents of regional experts highly skilled in colonial art.

column2: Chiclayo Municipal solid waste management
column25: Municipal and industrial solid waste management|Health, general, activity unspecified|Biosphere protection, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Composting and reuse|All water supply and sanitation education/training activities
column26: CHICLAYO MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT
column27: Municipal solid waste management (MSWM) in Peru is in a critical state and increasingly hampers the enormous (socio-) economic development potentials. mainly in the rapidly expanding cities in the coastal area such as Lima. Trujillo. Chiclayo. Piura or Tacna. The main problem is the uncontrolled final disposal of waste (almost 80%) in open-air dumps and other uncontrolled places (e.g. watercourses) by the vast majority of country's municipalities. The overall aim of the project is to provide a sustainable integrated municipal waste collection service to the population and enterprises of Chiclayo. from waste generation to environmental safe deposit. which could serve as reference of the national Chiclayo Municipal Solid Waste Management Project plan. The below components aim at rapid impacts with important demonstrating effects in order to gain social and political support for an integrated approach to MSWM: 1) Improvement of the service to the population; 2) Financial sustainability of the waste management municipal department; 3) Reduction of the impacts on the environment and the population health; 4) Improvement of the waste segregation at source and of waste recycling & reuse; 5) Improvement of public awareness on waste management and recycling.

column2: EMiS Peru Civil Society
column25: Community participation and development|General environmental protection, activity unspecified (includes miscellaneous conservation and protection measures not mentioned below) or does not fit under any other applicable codes
column26: EMIS PERU CIVIL SOCIETY
column27: To consolidate alliance with Coordinadora de Organizaciones Indígenas de la Cuenca Amazónica (COICA) and three of its member organizations in Peru, Ecuador and Colombia to devise COICA strategies with technical expertise on Climate Change, Energy and Extractive Industry topics while strengthen capacities in the three countries to develop innovative conservation and indigenous management proposals as a base for the mitigation of climate change, according to local sustainable development models.

column2: Human Rights Defenders - Disabled Peoples International 2011-2013 / Défenseurs des droits de la personne - Organisation mondiale des personnes handicappées 2011-2013
column25: Livestock/veterinary services|Agricultural research, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Agricultural inputs, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Agricultural water resources, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Livestock|Plant and post-harvest protection and pest control|Agricultural land resources, activity unspecified  or does not fit elsewhere in group|Forestry research, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group
column26: HUMAN RIGHTS DEFENDERS - DISABLED PEOPLES INTERNATIONAL 2011-2013 / DÉFENSEURS DES DROITS DE LA PERSONNE - ORGANISATION MONDIALE DES PERSONNES HANDICA
column27: The Disabled Peoples' International (DPI) project aims to positively influence the lives of people with disabilities in developing countries, more specifically in five CIDA Countries of Focus that have ratified the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD): Tanzania, Bangladesh, Peru, the Caribbean (Jamaica) and Ukraine. The project's objectives include: 1) strengthening the national and international dialogue on policy, legal, institutional, social, and economical issues that affect people with disabilities; and 2) strengthening the capacity of DPI members to promote awareness and enforcement of the CRPD and to use the reporting requirements under the CRPD to promote the rights of people with disabilities. The project helps to increase awareness, protection and enforcement of the rights of people with disabilities and enhance their inclusion and access to services. / Le projet de l'Organisation mondiale des personnes handicappées vise à influencer positivement la vie de personnes handicapées dans les pays en développement, en particulier dans cinq des pays de concentration de l'ACDI qui ont ratifié la Convention des droits des personnes handicapées, soit la Tanzanie, le Bangladesh, le Pérou, la Jamaïque et l'Ukraine. Les objectifs du projet comprennent : 1) le renforcement d'un dialogue national et international sur les enjeux politiques, légaux, institutionnels, sociaux et économiques qui affectent les personnes handicapées; 2) le renforcement de la capacité des membres de l'Organisation mondiale des personnes handicappées à favoriser la sensibilisation et la mise en application de la Convention, par exemple en utilisant l'obligation de rendre compte tel que proposée dans la Convention dans le but de promouvoir les droits des personnes handicapées. Le projet aide à augmenter la promotion, la protection et la défense des droits des personnes handicapées tout en rehaussant leur intégration et leur accès à des services.

column2: Canada World Youth - IAYI Internships 2011-2012 / Jeunesse Canada Monde - Stages SIJA 2011-2012
column25: Women in development, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Community participation and development|Human rights|Women's equality organisations and institutions
column26: CANADA WORLD YOUTH - IAYI INTERNSHIPS 2011-2012 / JEUNESSE CANADA MONDE - STAGES SIJA 2011-2012
column27: This project is part of CIDA's International Aboriginal Youth Internships (IAYI) initiative. The internships focus on increasing the awareness, engagement, and participation of Aboriginal youth in international development, while providing them with opportunities to expand their employment skills. CIDA provides up to $15,000 per internship to Canadian organizations that manage the internships and recruit interns. The IAYI initiative is part of CIDA's Global Citizens Program that seeks to raise awareness, increase knowledge and provide opportunities for youth to participate in international development. / Ce projet fait partie de l'initiative des Stages internationaux pour les jeunes Autochtones (SIJA) de l'ACDI. Ces stages visent à accroitre la sensibilisation, l'engagement et la participation des jeunes Autochtones à l'égard du développement international, tout en leur donnant la chance d'élargir leurs compétences professionnelles. L'ACDI fournit jusqu'à 15 000 $ par stage aux organisations canadiennes qui assurent la gestion des stages et le recrutement des stagiaires. L'initiative SIJA s'inscrit dans le programme Citoyens du monde de l'ACDI, un programme qui a comme objectif d'accroitre la sensibilisation, d'approfondir les connaissances et de fournir des occasions pour les jeunes de participer au développement international.

column2: CUSO-VSO - Volunteer Sending 2009-2014 / CUSO-VSO - Envoi de volontaires 2009-2014
column25: Institutional consensus, awareness, and capacity building
column26: CUSO-VSO - VOLUNTEER SENDING 2009-2014 / CUSO-VSO - ENVOI DE VOLONTAIRES 2009-2014
column27: As part of the 2009-2014 Volunteer Cooperation Program, CUSO-VSO places 1200 sector-focused skilled volunteers to build the capacity of partner organizations in 26 countries. Volunteer placements are both long- and short-term in nature, and include multiple types of volunteering options: North-South, South-South, South-North, national, Diaspora and business partnerships. Volunteers focus on capacity building (through sharing of knowledge, methodologies, and/or tools relating to specific capacity areas) and enhancing the ability of partners to influence development policy. Partners include local civil society organizations, national and local governments and various networks and associations CUSO-VSO also delivers a public engagement program in Canada designed to deepen understanding amongst Canadians and create opportunities for informed action on international development issues. CUSO-VSO works in the following sectors: Education, with a particular focus on the inclusion of women and girls in educational options; HIV and AIDS, with a particular focus on the vulnerability of woman and girls, and the rights of people to have access to services; Participation & Governance / Access to Justice, by aiming to empower poor and marginalized groups, especially women, to fulfill rights of access to basic services, and by ensuring access to justice for women and children; Youth Social and Economic Inclusion, by creating opportunities for training and employment for young women and men facing poverty, underemployment and social exclusion; Protecting Environments; Managing Natural Resources, by strengthening community-level governance mechanisms, including the participation of women in community decision-making, aimed at better local management of natural resources; Gender Equality, by incorporating GE as a crosscutting theme throughout all programming components, and through local GE capacity building activities with partners. An amount of $80,622 has been added to the total amount for each of the Volunteer Cooperation Agency programs for CIDA-led program evaluations. / Dans le cadre du Programme de coopération volontaire 2009-2014, CUSO-VSO place 1 200 volontaires compétents dans des secteurs ciblés afin de développer la capacité des organisations partenaires dans 26 pays. Les postes volontaires sont à la fois à court terme et à long terme et offrent de multiples options de volontariat : partenariats Nord-Sud, Sud-Sud, Sud-Nord, nationaux, de diaspora et d'affaires. Les volontaires se concentrent sur le développement des capacités par l'entremise du partage des connaissances, des méthodologies, ou des outils liés à des domaines particuliers en matière de capacité. Ils se concentrent également sur le rehaussement de la capacité des partenaires à influencer les politiques de développement. Les partenaires comprennent des organisations locales de la société civile, des gouvernements locaux et divers réseaux et associations. CUSO-VSO offre également un prog

Partners include local civil society organizations, national and local governments and various networks and associations CUSO-VSO also delivers a public engagement program in Canada designed to deepen understanding amongst Canadians and create opportunities for informed action on international development issues. CUSO-VSO works in the following sectors: Education, with a particular focus on the inclusion of women and girls in educational options; HIV and AIDS, with a particular focus on the vulnerability of woman and girls, and the rights of people to have access to services; Participation & Governance / Access to Justice, by aiming to empower poor and marginalized groups, especially women, to fulfill rights of access to basic services, and by ensuring access to justice for women and children; Youth Social and Economic Inclusion, by creating opportunities for training and employment for young women and men facing poverty, underemployment and social exclusion; Protecting Environments; Managing Natural Resources, by strengthening community-level governance mechanisms, including the participation of women in community decision-making, aimed at better local management of natural resources; Gender Equality, by incorporating GE as a crosscutting theme throughout all programming components, and through local GE capacity building activities with partners. An amount of $80,622 has been added to the total amount for each of the Volunteer Cooperation Agency programs for CIDA-led program evaluations. / Dans le cadre du Programme de coopération volontaire 2009-2014, CUSO-VSO place 1 200 volontaires compétents dans des secteurs ciblés afin de développer la capacité des organisations partenaires dans 26 pays. Les postes volontaires sont à la fois à court terme et à long terme et offrent de multiples options de volontariat : partenariats Nord-Sud, Sud-Sud, Sud-Nord, nationaux, de diaspora et d'affaires. Les volontaires se concentrent sur le développement des capacités par l'entremise du partage des connaissances, des méthodologies, ou des outils liés à des domaines particuliers en matière de capacité. Ils se concentrent également sur le rehaussement de la capacité des partenaires à influencer les politiques de développement. Les partenaires comprennent des organisations locales de la société civile, des gouvernements locaux et divers réseaux et associations. CUSO-VSO offre également un prog

column2: Support to the Forest Carbon Partnership Facility's Readiness Fund / Appui au Fonds de préparation du Fonds de partenariat pour le carbone forestier
column9: International Centre for the Prevention of Crime
column25: Food crop production
column26: SUPPORT TO THE FOREST CARBON PARTNERSHIP FACILITY'S READINESS FUND / APPUI AU FONDS DE PRÉPARATION DU FONDS DE PARTENARIAT POUR LE CARBONE FORESTIER
column27: This project supports the Readiness Fund of the Forest Carbon Partnership Facility (FCPF), which is a World Bank-managed facility that assists developing countries in their efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation and forest degradation. It also promotes conservation, sustainable management of forests and enhancement of forest carbon stocks. The FCPF has the dual objective of building capacity in developing countries in tropical and subtropical regions (Readiness Fund), and testing a program of performance-based incentive payments in selected pilot countries on a relatively small scale (Carbon Fund). CIDA's contribution to the FCPF Readiness Fund supports national capacity building to address the problem of deforestation and forest degradation, by providing technical and financial assistance to countries in the development of their strategies. / Ce projet appuie le Fonds de préparation du Fonds de partenariat pour le carbone forestier (FCPF), une infrastructure dirigée par la Banque mondiale qui a pour but de soutenir les efforts déployés par les pays en développement pour réduire les émissions de gaz à effet de serre produites par le déboisement et le dépérissement de la forêt. Il appuie également la conservation et la gestion durable des forêts ainsi que l'amélioration des réserves de carbone forestier. Le FCPF vise non seulement à bâtir les capacités des pays en développement des régions tropicales et subtropicales (Fonds de préparation), mais aussi à mettre à l'essai, à une échelle relativement petite, un programme d'incitatifs financiers axés sur le rendement dans certains pays sélectionnés (Fonds pour le carbone). La contribution de l'Agence canadienne de développement international au Fonds de préparation du FCPF soutient le renforcement des capacités nationales qui ont pour but de remédier au problème du déboisement et du dépérissement de la forêt. Cette contribution sous forme d'aide technique et financière soutient les pays en développement dans le cadre de l'élaboration de leurs stratégies.

column2: SUCO - Volunteer Sending 2009-2014 / SUCO - Envoi de volontaires 2009-2014
column9: International Centre for the Prevention of Crime
column25: Recovery and reconstruction, activity unspecified|Reconstruction assistance
column26: SUCO - VOLUNTEER SENDING 2009-2014 / SUCO - ENVOI DE VOLONTAIRES 2009-2014
column27: The program concentrates its activities in three sectors: private sector development through partners' institutional and organizational strengthening; good governance through local development; and promotion of environmental sustainability through agriculture, forestry, fish and cattle farming systems. Every year, 22 volunteers support these efforts. The objectives of the program are: (1) help partners gain knowledge and adopt development practices that are democratic, just and sustainable; (2) help partners improve individual and collective well-being through socio-economic activities; (3) promote gender equity and empower women in gaining autonomy and influence; (4) support partners in their actions and practices leading towards viable and sustainable environmental development; and (5) promote openness for exchange and dialogue between development partners (government authorities and civil society organizations). An amount of $80,622 has been added to the total amount for each of the Volunteer Cooperation Agency programs for CIDA-led program evaluations. / Le programme concentre ses actions dans trois secteurs, soit le soutien au développement du secteur privé par le renforcement institutionnel et organisationnel de partenaires, la promotion de la bonne gouvernance par le développement local et la promotion de la durabilité de l'environnement par des systèmes agro-sylvo-pastoraux et piscicoles. Il y a 22 volontaires par année qui appuient ces efforts. Les objectifs du programme visent à 1) appuyer les partenaires à acquérir et adopter des pratiques de développement démocratique, équitable et durable; 2) soutenir les partenaires dans des actions socio-économiques permettant d'améliorer le mieux-être individuel et collectif des populations visées; 3) contribuer à la promotion de l'égalité entre les femmes et les hommes et soutenir les femmes dans l'atteinte d'une plus grande autonomie d'action et d'une plus grande influence; 4) soutenir les partenaires dans leurs actions et pratiques menant à un développement environnemental viable et durable; 5) favoriser la création d'espaces d'échanges et de dialogues entre partenaires du développement (instances gouvernementales et organisations de la société civile). Un montant de $ 80 622 a été ajouté au montant total pour chaque programme des organisations de coopération volontaire, pour les évaluations de programmes menées par l'ACDI.

column2: Fair Access to and Benefit Sharing of Genetic Resources : National Policy Development (China, Jordan, Nepal, Peru)
column25: All other activities when sector is not specified
column26: FAIR ACCESS TO AND BENEFIT SHARING OF GENETIC RESOURCES : NATIONAL POLICY DEVELOPMENT (CHINA, JORDAN, NEPAL, PERU)
column27: Local practices pertaining to biodiversity conservation, crop improvement and natural resource management are under stress. Existing laws and mechanisms - such as intellectual property rights (IPRs) - leave communities open to biopiracy because they protect individual as opposed to collective rights and do not recognize traditional knowledge or collaborative innovations such as varieties developed through participatory plant breeding. This project will bring together experienced research teams (China, Jordan, Nepal and Peru ) and international technical and legal experts to work on much needed policies, laws and practices for the fair use and management of genetic resources. The focus will be on innovations that are grounded in the practices of local and indigenous farming communities, and supported by partnerships with concerned stakeholders.The project is expected to result in practical mechanisms for fair access and benefit sharing; policy and legal recommendations pertaining to biopiracy, crop improvement, variety release, seed production and farmer organization; country case studies; scientific papers; a book; and training materials in English and indigenous languages.

column2: Employment and Income in Bolivia, Paraguay and Peru : Analysis of the Links between Labour Demand and Supply
column25: General government services not elsewhere specified|Agriculture, activity unspecified or does not fit under any other applicable codes|All unspecified multisector aid activities|Social/welfare services, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in this group|General environmental protection, activity unspecified (includes miscellaneous conservation and protection measures not mentioned below) or does not fit under any other applicable codes|Employment policy and administrative management, activity unspecified or does not fit elsewhere in group|Health, activity unspecified or does not fit under any other applicable codes
column26: EMPLOYMENT AND INCOME IN BOLIVIA, PARAGUAY AND PERU : ANALYSIS OF THE LINKS BETWEEN LABOUR DEMAND AND SUPPLY
column27: Like many countries in Latin America, Bolivia, Paraguay and Peru undertook structural reforms during the 1980s and 1990s with a view to achieving macroeconomic stability and economic growth. Growth was expected to generate more and better jobs for their combined population of 40 million. Although economic growth resumed after the reforms - especially since 2004 - none of the countries experienced significant improvement in their employment outcomes. All three have persistent levels of poverty and higher-than-average income disparity, even by Latin American standards. Any substantive reduction in poverty will depend on increasing the demand for labour, rather than economic growth alone. This project will investigate how small productive units - the largest source of employment in all three countries - have managed to create and sustain employment since the reforms. The research anticipates that a package of policies in support of good labour market outcomes will likely involve policy recommendations that go beyond the labour sector.

column2: Scaling-up Rural Innovations (Peru)
column9: OrganizaciÃ³n no Gubernamental de Desarrollo Programa Regional de CapacitaciÃ³n en Desarrollo Rural
column25: Food crop production|Environmental policy, laws, regulations and economic instruments
column26: SCALING-UP RURAL INNOVATIONS (PERU)
column27: Confronted with changing environments and growing poverty and inequalities, many small-scale farmers from the Andes have been forced to adopt innovative livelihood strategies. They have done this by combining practical knowledge, local talent and external assets to manage their natural resources in creative and novel ways - ways that result in increased food and income security, and allow them to escape from poverty. This project will explore ways of stimulating and scaling up the innovations of small-scale farmers. In collaboration with stakeholders, researchers will examine instances of scaled-up innovation in farm production, natural resource management and off-farm income generation and develop policies and programs in consequence. The project will focus initially on Peru and be extended to other Andean countries, and potentially Africa.

column2: Impacts of Climate Variability and Climate Change on the Mangrove Ecosystem in Tumbes, Peru
column26: IMPACTS OF CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE MANGROVE ECOSYSTEM IN TUMBES, PERU
column27: The mangrove ecosystem of Tumbes plays a pivotal role in providing protection against tides, winds and storm surges, and habitat for a number of fish species. The native coastal communities of Tumbes rely on artisanal fishing for food and income generation. Already under threat from water pollution, deforestation and overfishing (black conch), climate change is affecting the stability and health of the mangrove ecosystem through increased sea level rise and variable rainfall. For example, reduced water flows during the dry season increase the salinity of the mangrove waters, while intense precipitation during the rainy season dilutes saline waters and increases sediment loads. Sustainable management of mangrove ecosystems is currently compromised by lack of basic scientific information.This project aims to improve understanding of the ecosystem so that its human population can prepare effectively for the impacts of climate variability. Researchers, in cooperation with community associations, local authorities and other stakeholders, will document the impact of climate variability on the ecology and sustainability of the mangrove ecosystem, investigate the sensitivity of the black conch (Andara tuberculosa) and other species to changing salinity and sediment levels, and assess the economic value of environmental services provided by the mangrove ecosystem.The project is expected to lead to the development of an adaptation plan for the mangrove ecosystem and local communities, including a concerted sustainable management plan for the extraction of the black conch. Given the importance of mangrove ecosystems to coastal areas throughout the world, this research has the potential to make a contribution to adaptation efforts by coastal communities beyond Peru.
